Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Disability Rating Scale as a Predictor of Long-term Outcome in Severe Traumatic Brain Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised to receive erythropoietin or placebo

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria encompassed adults with severe TBI, and the study was conducted across multiple trauma centers.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive erythropoietin or placebo

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the Disability Rating Scale (DRS) as a predictor of favorable 6-month Glasgow Outcome Scale extended (GOS-E).

Method_Outcome.evidence: DRS was recorded weekly from weeks 1 to 4 post-injury, and GOS-E was evaluated at 6 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 assigned to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The model using baseline demographic and injury severity variables with week 1 DRS achieved an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 0.82, which increased to 0.88 when including weekly DRS until week 4.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group, with mild side effects occurring in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.
